choices.text: Eustachian tube
Mastoid air cells
Aditus to mastoid antrum
Internal auditory canal

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the middle ear cleft?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal auditory canal

 

The middle ear cleft is an anatomically connected air-filled system that includes:

 

  • Eustachian tube – connects the nasopharynx to the middle ear and helps in pressure equalization.
  • Middle ear cavity (tympanum) – houses the ossicles.
  • Aditus to mastoid antrum – a communication channel between the epitympanum and mastoid antrum.
  • Mastoid antrum and air cells – air-filled spaces within the mastoid bone, connected via the aditus.

 

These structures form a continuous pathway for air and potential infections (e.g., from acute otitis media to mastoiditis).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option D. Internal auditory canal: 

 

  • This canal lies within the petrous part of the temporal bone and transmits the facial and vestibulocochlear nerves.
  • It is not air-filled and is not part of the middle ear cleft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle ear cleft includes the Eustachian tube, middle ear cavity, aditus, mastoid antrum, and mastoid air cells.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: It is formed by the round window
Scutum is located on the medial wall of the middle ear
Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear
Scutum is part of the posterior wall of the middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the lateral wall of the middle ear is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tympanic membrane forms the lateral wall of the middle ear

 

The lateral wall of the middle ear is primarily formed by the tympanic membrane, which separates the external auditory canal (outer ear) from the middle ear cavity. Hence, it also represents the medial wall of the external ear.

 

Additionally, the scutum is a small bony plate forming the superior part of the lateral wall of the epitympanum (attic). It is a key landmark in cholesteatoma, which often erodes it.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is formed by the round window: The round window lies on the medial wall of the middle ear cavity, just below the oval window.

 

Option B. Scutum is located on the medial wall of the middle ear: The scutum is part of the lateral bony wall, above the tympanic membrane (attic region).

 

Option D. Scutum is part of the posterior wall of the middle ear: The scutum is located anterior-lateral, in the attic region (lateral wall of epitympanum), not posterior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral wall of the middle ear is formed by the tympanic membrane and the scutum, which is often eroded in cholesteatoma.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: Chorda tympani nerve arises above the level of the facial nerve in the middle ear and exits via the facial recess
Facial recess is located between the incus and facial nerve, with the stapes forming its roof
The stapedius muscle arises from the pyramid and inserts into the anterior crus of the stapes
The facial nerve gives off the chorda tympani below the middle ear and runs vertically in the posterior wall

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the posterior wall of the middle ear is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The facial nerve gives off the chorda tympani below the middle ear and runs vertically in the posterior wall

 

The posterior wall of the middle ear houses several critical structures, both anatomical and surgical landmarks:

 

  • The facial nerve runs vertically in the posterior wall after its first genu (turn) at the medial wall.
  • It gives off the chorda tympani branch just below the level of the middle ear cavity.
  • Chorda tympani then ascends to enter the middle ear cavity, runs between the malleus and incus, and exits anteriorly through the canal of Huguier in the Glasserian (petrotympanic) fissure to supply taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

For video demonstration of endoscopic anatomy of middle ear, scan the below QR code:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chorda tympani nerve arises above the level of the facial nerve in the middle ear and exits via the facial recess: Incorrect

 

  • Chorda tympani arises below the level of the middle ear cavity and travels upward into it.
  • It exits not through the facial recess, but through the canal of Huguier in the anterior lateral wall.

 

Option B. Facial recess is located between the incus and facial nerve, with the stapes forming its roof : Incorrect

 

  • The facial recess is bordered:
    • Medially: facial nerve
    • Laterally: chorda tympani
    • Superiorly: short process of incus
  • It is the key landmark for posterior tympanotomy, not related to the stapes.

 

Option C. The stapedius muscle arises from the pyramid and inserts into the anterior crus of the stapes: Incorrect

 

  • The stapedius muscle arises from the pyramidal eminence on the posterior wall.
  • It inserts into the posterior crus of the stapes (not the anterior).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial nerve runs vertically in the posterior wall of the middle ear and gives off the chorda tympani below the cavity, which travels upward between the malleus and incus and exits via the canal of Huguier; the stapedius muscle arises from the pyramid and inserts on the posterior crus of the stapes, and the facial recess lies between the chorda tympani and facial nerve with the incus short process forming its superior boundary.

choices.text: It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it
It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus
It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it
It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes MacEwen’s triangle, a key surgical landmark in mastoid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It helps identify the mastoid antrum, which lies approximately 1.5 cm deep to it

 

MacEwen’s triangle is a key surgical surface landmark used during mastoidectomy to locate the mastoid antrum, especially in pediatric cases where landmarks can be variable.

 

  • The mastoid antrum lies about 1.5 cm deep to MacEwen’s triangle, making it an essential guide in mastoid surgeries.
  • This triangle is located behind the external auditory canal and guides safe entry during cortical mastoidectomy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is used to identify the facial recess, which lies 1.5 cm deep to it: Incorrect

 

  • The facial recess lies within the middle ear, not related to MacEwen’s triangle.
  • The facial recess is identified between the facial nerve and chorda tympani, not through surface landmarks.

 

Option B. It is bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, zygomatic arch, and sigmoid sinus:  Incorrect

 

  • The actual boundaries of MacEwen’s triangle are:
    • Anteriorly: Posterosuperior meatal wall
    • Superiorly: Temporal line
    • Posteriorly: A vertical tangent to the posterior canal wall
  • The zygomatic arch and sigmoid sinus are unrelated to its boundaries.

 

Option D. It is bordered superiorly by the parietal eminence and anteriorly by the Eustachian tube: Incorrect

 

  • These landmarks are not related to the triangle.
  • The temporal line, not the parietal eminence, forms the superior boundary, and the Eustachian tube is not part of the surface triangle anatomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MacEwen’s triangle is a surface landmark bounded by the posterosuperior meatal wall, temporal line, and a posterior tangent to the external canal, used to identify the mastoid antrum located approximately 1.5 cm deep to it.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5,6

choices.text: By fibrous bands at two points of contact
By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery
Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule
By a fluid seal formed by the round window membrane

questions.text: How is the stapes footplate attached to the oval window of the cochlea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) By the annular ligament circumferentially along its periphery

 

The stapes is the third and innermost ossicle in the middle ear, and its footplate plays a critical role in transmitting sound vibrations into the inner ear:

 

  • The footplate of the stapes fits into the oval window (fenestra vestibuli) of the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • It is held in place by the annular ligament, which attaches around the entire periphery of the footplate in a circumferential manner.
  • This allows the footplate to vibrate and transmit mechanical energy to the perilymph of the scala vestibuli in the cochlea.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By fibrous bands at two points of contact: Incorrect

 

  • There are no two-point fibrous attachments; the connection is circular and uniform, not focal.

 

Option C. Through a direct bony fusion with the vestibule: Incorrect

 

  • A bony fusion at this site would impede movement, as occurs in otosclerosis.
  • Under normal conditions, the stapes is not fused, but freely mobile, thanks to the annular ligament.

 

Option D. By a fluid seal formed by the round window membrane: Incorrect

 

  • The round window is located below the oval window, and is unrelated to stapes attachment.
  • It acts as a pressure-release valve during cochlear fluid movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stapes footplate is attached to the oval window via the annular ligament in a circumferential manner, allowing sound transmission to the inner ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: It is caused by bony overgrowth at the round window and primarily leads to sensorineural hearing loss
It commonly presents in young white females and worsens during pregnancy
It is associated with Ehler-Danlos syndrome and characterized by red sclera
It most often affects elderly males and is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding stapedial otosclerosis is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It commonly presents in young white females and worsens during pregnancy

 

Stapedial otosclerosis is a type of otosclerosis where irregular spongy bone is deposited around the anterior part of the stapes footplate and the fissula ante fenestram (area just anterior to the oval window).

 

This fixes the stapes, impeding its movement, thereby disrupting sound conduction and causing conductive hearing loss.

 

It commonly presents in:

 

  • Young adults (20–30 years)
  • White females
  • May worsen during pregnancy due to hormonal influences
  • Has a positive family history (often autosomal dominant)
  • Associated with blue sclera and osteogenesis imperfecta in Van der Hoeve syndrome

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused by bony overgrowth at the round window and primarily leads to sensorineural hearing loss: Incorrect

 

  • The round window is not primarily involved.
  • Stapedial otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural.

 

Option C. It is associated with Ehler-Danlos syndrome and characterized by red sclera: Incorrect

 

  • The associated condition is Van der Hoeve syndrome, not Ehler-Danlos.
  • The classic triad includes:
    • Otosclerosis
    • Blue sclera
    • Osteogenesis imperfecta

 

Option D. It most often affects elderly males and is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern: Incorrect

 

  • It affects younger individuals, especially females.
  • Inheritance is typically autosomal dominant, not recessive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stapedial otosclerosis is caused by spongy bone deposition at the footplate and fissula ante fenestram, leading to conductive hearing loss and commonly affecting young white females, especially during pregnancy, with associations like blue sclera and autosomal dominant inheritance.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media
Otosclerosis
Cochlear ototoxicity
Tympanosclerosis

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with progressive hearing loss. She reports that she hears better in noisy environments. Otoscopy reveals an intact tympanic membrane with a reddish hue over the promontory. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

 

  • All features (Carhart notch, Schwartz sign, paracusis Willisi, intact TM, conductive loss) point to this diagnosis.

 

This patient presents with classic features of otosclerosis, as highlighted in the image:

 

  • Progressive hearing loss (most common presentation)
  • Paracusis Willisi: hears better in noisy surroundings – a hallmark feature
  • Otoscopy: Intact tympanic membrane, with Schwartz sign (reddish hue on promontory) → seen in active otospongiosis
  • Pure tone audiometry: Carhart’s notch → dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction curve
  • Tuning fork tests: Rinne negative, Weber lateralizes to poorer ear → conductive hearing loss
  • Most common site: Fissula ante fenestram
  • Treatment of choice: Surgery, especially stapedotomy

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic suppurative otitis media: Usually presents with perforated tympanic membrane and discharge, not an intact TM or Carhart’s notch.

 

Option C. Cochlear ototoxicity: Leads to sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive. No Carhart’s notch or Schwartz sign.

 

Option D. Tympanosclerosis: Involves hyalinization or calcification post-infection, and TM may appear chalky or thickened – not reddish and intact with 2000 Hz dip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otosclerosis presents with conductive hearing loss, intact TM, Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz, paracusis Willisi, and Schwartz sign; treatment of choice is stapedotomy.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Tympanic membrane is mildly retracted with prominence of the lateral process of the malleus
Tympanic membrane adheres to the ossicles (incus or stapes)
Tympanic membrane contacts the promontory
Tympanic membrane is plastered over ossicles and promontory with loss of aeration

questions.text: According to the Sade classification of tympanic membrane retraction, which of the following correctly describes Grade 3 retraction of the pars tensa?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tympanic membrane contacts the promontory

 

The Sade classification is used to grade retraction of the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane, which can progress due to chronic negative middle ear pressure (often from Eustachian tube dysfunction).

 

Grade 1:

  • Mild retraction, with increased visibility of the lateral process of malleus
  • Option A corresponds to this – Not Grade 3

 

Grade 2:

  • Tympanic membrane contacts ossicles, such as incus or stapes
  • Option B corresponds to Grade 2 – Not Grade 3

 

Grade 3:

  • Tympanic membrane contacts the promontory
  • Option C is correct for Grade 3

 

Grade 4:

  • Adhesive otitis media – the membrane is tightly plastered over ossicles and promontory, no middle ear aeration
  • Option D fits Grade 4 – Not Grade 3

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Sade classification, Grade 3 pars tensa retraction is when the tympanic membrane comes into contact with the promontory.

choices.text: Right-sided sensorineural hearing loss
Left-sided conductive hearing loss
Left-sided sensorineural hearing loss
Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss

questions.text:
A patient presents with hearing loss in the left ear. On examination:

 

  • Rinne test is negative on the left (BC > AC)
  • Weber test lateralizes to the left ear
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left-sided conductive hearing loss

 

Left-sided CHL: Correct. Matches all test findings

 

Rinne Test

  • AC > BC → Normal or Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
  • BC > AC (Rinne Negative) → Conductive hearing loss (CHL)
    → Patient has Rinne negative on the left → Suggests CHL on left

 

Weber Test

  • Lateralizes to affected ear in CHL
  • Lateralizes to normal ear in SNHL
    → Here, Weber lateralizes to left → Supports CHL on left

 

Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC)

  • Compares bone conduction between patient and examiner (normal ear)
    → In SNHL, patient's bone conduction is worse
    → In CHL, bone conduction remains normal or prolonged

 

Putting it all together:

  • Rinne negative on left
  • Weber lateralizes to left
    → Classic for left-sided CHL

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right-sided SNHL: No Rinne or Weber findings supporting right ear involvement

 

Option C. Left-sided SNHL: Would have Rinne positive and Weber lateralizing to right – not seen here

 

Option D. Bilateral SNHL: Would show midline Weber and Rinne positive bilaterally – not applicable here

 

Educational Objective:

 

In tuning fork tests, a negative Rinne test with Weber lateralizing to the same ear suggests conductive hearing loss in that ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: Otitis media with effusion
Partial fixation of the footplate of stapes
Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane
Malleus-incus disruption with tympanic membrane perforation

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is likely to cause the maximum degree of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane

 

Hearing loss in middle ear conditions depends on whether the ossicular chain remains intact and how effectively sound waves are transmitted to the inner ear:

 

  • Here, the ossicular chain is broken, and the tympanic membrane is intact.
  • Sound waves hit the TM, but due to disruption of continuity, no transmission occurs to the oval window.
  • Maximum hearing loss occurs because energy gets absorbed/dampened.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otitis media with effusion (OME): Incorrect

 

  • Causes a mild-to-moderate conductive hearing loss due to fluid dampening sound, but ossicles are intact.
  • Hearing loss is typically < 40 dB.

 

Option B. Partial fixation of stapes footplate: Incorrect

 

  • Seen in early otosclerosis.
  • Causes progressive conductive hearing loss, but as some vibration is still transmitted, the loss is less severe than in complete ossicular discontinuity.

 

Option D. Malleus-incus disruption with tympanic membrane perforation: Incorrect

 

  • Despite ossicular disruption, TM perforation allows some sound waves to directly strike the round window, causing inner ear fluid movement.
  • Some hearing is retained, so loss is less than in option C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossicular discontinuity with intact tympanic membrane causes maximum conductive hearing loss due to total interruption of sound transmission to the inner ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 23

choices.text: Moderate sensorineural hearing loss
Severe conductive hearing loss
Severe sensorineural hearing loss
Profound mixed hearing loss

questions.text: A patient’s audiogram shows bilateral hearing thresholds between 75–95 dB across all frequencies, with no air-bone gap. What is the most likely type and degree of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe sensorineural hearing loss

 

  • Both AC and BC thresholds are elevated
  • No air-bone gap
  • Thresholds fall in 75–95 dB range → Severe SNHL

 

Interpreting the Audiogram:

 

  • The graph shows hearing thresholds for both ears (X = left, O = right) around 75 to 95 dB at all frequencies.
  • No significant air-bone gap is seen, implying both air and bone conduction are equally impaired.
  • This is indicative of sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).
  • Thresholds between 71–90 dB fall under severe hearing loss as per WHO and audiological classifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moderate sensorineural hearing loss:

 

  • Moderate SNHL = 41–60 dB
  • This audiogram shows higher thresholds, ruling this out.

 

Option B. Severe conductive hearing loss:

 

  • In conductive loss, air conduction is impaired, but bone conduction is normal, creating an air-bone gap.
  • No such gap is seen here.

 

Option D. Profound mixed hearing loss:

 

  • Profound = >90 dB, mixed = air-bone gap with both elevated
  • While some thresholds reach 90+, there is no AB gap, so this is not mixed

 

Educational Objective:

 

An audiogram with elevated air and bone conduction thresholds (75–95 dB) and no air-bone gap indicates severe sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 23

choices.text: Type A – Normal middle ear pressure and mobility
Type B – Otitis media with effusion or perforated tympanic membrane
Type C – Eustachian tube dysfunction
Type Ad – Ossicular discontinuity or hypermobile TM

questions.text: A patient undergoes tympanometry, and the graph shows a peak at -150 daPa with reduced compliance. Which of the following tympanogram types does this indicate, and what is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type C – Eustachian tube dysfunction

 

  • Peak at -150 daPa, reduced compliance → consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Tympanometry measures middle ear pressure and tympanic membrane compliance:

 

Type A:

  • Peak at 0 daPa
  • Indicates normal middle ear pressure and compliance

 

Type As (shallow):

  • Peak at 0 daPa but reduced compliance
  • Seen in otosclerosis or tympanosclerosis

 

Type Ad (deep):

  • Peak at 0 daPa but excessively high compliance
  • Seen in ossicular chain discontinuity or flaccid TM

 

Type C:

  • Peak is shifted to negative pressure (usually -100 to -200 daPa)
  • Suggests Eustachian tube dysfunction

 

Type B:

  • Flat curve, no peak
  • Indicates fluid in middle ear, perforated TM, or wax occlusion

 

 

A – Normal

As – Otosclerosis

Ad – Ossicular discontinuity

B – OME, CSOM

C – Retracted tympanic membrane

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A – Normal middle ear pressure and mobility: Peak at 0 daPa; not consistent with -150 daPa.

 

Option B. Type B – Otitis media with effusion or perforated tympanic membrane: Shows flat curve, not a shifted peak.

 

Option D. Type Ad – Ossicular discontinuity or hypermobile TM: Would show very high peak at 0 daPa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A tympanogram showing a peak at negative pressure (e.g., -150 daPa) with reduced compliance is classified as Type C, indicating Eustachian tube dysfunction.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 25

choices.text: Rinne's test – negative; Weber's test – lateralized to right ear
Rinne's test – negative; Weber's test – lateralized to left ear
Rinne's test – positive; Weber's test – lateralized to left ear
Rinne's test – positive; Weber's test – lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss in the left ear. On examination, the physician suspects Ménière’s disease. Which of the following tuning fork test patterns is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinne's test – positive; Weber's test – lateralized to right ear

 

Ménière’s disease causes unilateral fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), most often affecting low frequencies early on.

 

  • Rinne’s Test:
    • In SNHL, air conduction (AC) remains better than bone conduction (BC) → Rinne positive
  • Weber’s Test:
    • In SNHL, sound lateralizes to the better ear
    • Since the left ear is affected, Weber lateralizes to the right ear

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinne's test – negative; Weber's test – lateralized to right ear: Rinne negative → seen in conductive hearing loss, not SNHL

 

Option B. Rinne's test – negative; Weber's test – lateralized to left ear:  Same as above

 

Option C. Rinne's test – positive; Weber's test – lateralized to left ear: SNHL causes lateralization to better (opposite) ear, not affected side

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Ménière’s disease (SNHL), Rinne's test is positive and Weber’s test lateralizes to the better ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 21

choices.text: Chorda tympani
Auriculotemporal nerve
Greater auricular nerve
Nerve to mylohyoid

questions.text: A patient develops sweating and flushing over the cheek while eating, following parotid gland surgery. Frey’s syndrome is suspected. Which of the following nerves is involved in the aberrant reinnervation responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auriculotemporal nerve

 

  • Final carrier of secretomotor fibres to parotid; responsible for Frey’s syndrome when misdirected.

 

Frey’s syndrome (gustatory sweating) occurs due to:

 

  • Aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres after parotid gland surgery or trauma.
  • Parasympathetic secretomotor fibres (originally destined for the parotid gland) regenerate incorrectly and innervate sweat glands of the overlying skin.
  • As a result, sweating and flushing occur over the parotid region while eating (gustatory stimulus).

 

The auriculotemporal nerve:

 

  • Is a branch of mandibular nerve (V3)
  • Carries postganglionic parasympathetic fibres from the otic ganglion to the parotid gland
  • Final step of the tympanic plexus → lesser petrosal → otic ganglion → auriculotemporal → parotid pathway

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chorda tympani: Carries secretomotor fibres to submandibular and sublingual glands, not parotid.

 

Option C. Greater auricular nerve: Supplies cutaneous sensation over parotid region but is not involved in salivation.

 

Option D. Nerve to mylohyoid: Motor branch to mylohyoid and anterior belly of digastric; no secretomotor role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frey’s syndrome results from aberrant regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres that originally carried secretomotor supply to the parotid gland.

 

Parasympathetic pathway to the parotid gland :-

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8

choices.text: Schwabach shorter in patient than examiner
Schwabach equal in patient and examiner
Schwabach prolonged in patient compared to examiner
Schwabach not interpretable without masking

questions.text: In Schwabach’s test, bone conduction is compared between the patient and a normal-hearing examiner without occluding the external auditory canal. Which of the following results correctly indicates conductive hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Schwabach prolonged in patient compared to examiner

 

Schwabach prolonged in patient: Correct. Classic for conductive hearing loss

 

Schwabach’s test:

 

  • Compares bone conduction (BC) of the patient vs examiner
  • Unlike ABC test, external auditory canal is not occluded
  • It helps differentiate sensorineural from conductive hearing loss

 

Interpretation:

 

  • Normal:
    • Patient hears bone-conducted sound for the same duration as examiner
  • Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL):
    • Patient’s cochlear function is reduced → hears for a shorter duration
      → Schwabach is reduced
  • Conductive Hearing Loss (CHL):
    • Sound is not dampened by the middle ear structures due to their dysfunction
    • Bone conduction bypasses middle ear, and no ambient noise via air competes
      → Patient may hear sound longer than examiner
      → Schwabach is prolonged

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schwabach shorter in patient than examiner: Seen in sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive

 

Option B. Schwabach equal in patient and examiner: Seen in normal hearing, not in pathology

 

Option D. Schwabach not interpretable without masking: Masking is not standard for Schwabach; used in ABC and Weber if needed

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwabach test is prolonged in conductive hearing loss and reduced in sensorineural hearing loss due to changes in cochlear function.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated
A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear
The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies
A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the principle and interpretation of the Stenger test in a patient suspected of feigning unilateral hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A malingerer will deny hearing any sound when the stimulus is stronger in the "deaf" ear and weaker in the normal ear

 

Malingerer denies hearing when louder sound is in feigned deaf ear – Correct

 

Stenger test is a behavioral test used to detect non-organic or feigned unilateral hearing loss. It works on the Stenger principle:

 

When two tones of the same frequency but different intensities are presented simultaneously to both ears, the patient only perceives the louder tone.

 

How the test works:

 

  • Start by presenting equal-frequency sounds (via tuning forks or audiometer) to both ears.
  • Then move the sound closer to the side of the claimed deafness (i.e., make the sound louder in the "deaf" ear).
  • If the patient is truly deaf, they will continue to hear the tone in the normal ear.
  • If the patient is malingering, the louder sound in the "deaf" ear suppresses the softer one in the normal ear (per the Stenger principle), but the patient claims not to hear anything at all, revealing the deception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient with true unilateral deafness hears sound only in the affected ear when both ears are stimulated: Incorrect. A truly deaf ear won’t perceive sound; patient hears via normal ear.

 

Option C. The test is used to confirm bilateral conductive hearing loss using tuning forks of different frequencies: Stenger test is not diagnostic for bilateral conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. A positive Stenger test confirms the diagnosis of sensorineural hearing loss in both ears: The test does not confirm SNHL in both ears; it's used for unilateral malingering.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Stenger test is used to detect unilateral malingering; if a patient denies hearing when a louder tone is presented to the "deaf" ear, it indicates feigned hearing loss (positive Stenger test).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: 25%
31.25%
37.5%
45%

questions.text:
A patient undergoes audiometry with the following air conduction thresholds:

 

 

What is the total hearing handicap percentage for this patient using the standard formula described for compensation purposes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 37.5%

 

To calculate hearing handicap percentage:

 

Total percentage handicap of an individual

 

 

Step 1: Average hearing loss

  • Right ear: (60 + 75 + 90) / 3 = 75 dB
  • Left ear: (30 + 45 + 60) / 3 = 45 dB

 

Step 2: Subtract 25 dB

  • Right ear: 75 – 25 = 50 dB
  • Left ear: 45 – 25 = 20 dB

 

Step 3: Multiply by 1.5

  • Right ear impairment = 50 × 1.5 = 75%
  • Left ear impairment = 20 × 1.5 = 30%

 

Step 4: Calculate total handicap

(30 × 5) + 75 / 6 = 225/6 = 37.5%

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25%: Too low, likely missing one or more steps

 

Option B. 31.25%: Incorrect math

 

Option D. 45%: Overestimated, possibly used wrong formula

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hearing handicap percentage is calculated using the formula: (better ear % × 5 + worse ear %) ÷ 6, after deducting 25 dB from average thresholds and multiplying by 1.5.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 39

choices.text: A history of Ménière’s disease with vertigo
Presence of tympanic membrane perforation
History of frequent air travel
Conductive hearing loss with bilateral involvement

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to stapes surgery in a patient with otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A history of Ménière’s disease with vertigo

 

Ménière’s disease with vertigo is a clear contraindication due to risk of worsening sensorineural hearing loss

 

Stapes surgery (e.g., stapedotomy or stapedectomy) is a definitive treatment for conductive hearing loss due to otosclerosis, but it has specific contraindications due to risk of complications or poor outcomes:

 

Absolute Contraindications:

 

  1. Only hearing ear – risk of total hearing loss post-op
  2. Associated Ménière’s disease – increased risk of SNHL post-surgery due to inner ear pathology
  3. Young children – higher recurrence due to Eustachian tube dysfunction and fast-growing otospongiosis
  4. Professional athletes/divers/construction workers – post-op vertigo or barotrauma risk
  5. Working in noisy environments – increased risk of noise-induced SNHL after surgery

 

Relative Contraindications:

 

  • Otitis externa, TM perforation, exostosis – can proceed once treated
  • Pregnancy – avoid due to anesthesia/surgical stress
  • Surgery is preferably done under local anesthesia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Presence of tympanic membrane perforation: TM perforation is a relative contraindication; surgery can be done after TM is repaired

 

Option C. History of frequent air travel: Frequent air travel is a concern but not absolute—it's due to pressure sensitivity and risk of post-op vertigo

 

Option D. Conductive hearing loss with bilateral involvement: Bilateral CHL is actually a typical indication for surgery (one ear at a time)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ménière’s disease is an absolute contraindication to stapes surgery due to high risk of postoperative sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Preoperative biopsy is avoided due to high vascularity and risk of injury
CT scan using bone window helps identify caroticojugular spine erosion in glomus jugulare
Serum catecholamines and urinary VMA levels are checked in all patients
MRI is not useful in assessing the soft tissue extent or vascular invasion

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis and workup of glomus tumors is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MRI is not useful in assessing the soft tissue extent or vascular invasion

 

MRI is highly useful in glomus tumors. It provides excellent information about the soft tissue extent and with MR angiography/venography, helps assess vascular invasion like jugular vein or carotid artery involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preoperative biopsy is avoided due to high vascularity and risk of injury: Correct. Preoperative biopsy is contraindicated in glomus tumors due to their high vascularity and risk of profuse bleeding. There's also danger of damaging nearby vascular structures like jugular bulb or aberrant carotid artery.

 

Option B. CT scan using bone window helps identify caroticojugular spine erosion in glomus jugulare: Correct. A CT scan with bone window and thin (1 mm) slices is crucial for detecting erosion of the caroticojugular spine, which helps differentiate glomus jugulare (erosion present) from glomus tympanicum.

 

Option C. Serum catecholamines and urinary VMA levels are checked in all patients: Correct. As some glomus tumors secrete catecholamines, it's important to assess serum levels and urinary breakdown products like VMA and metanephrines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagnosis of glomus tumors involves CT and MRI imaging for extent and differentiation, biochemical screening for catecholamine secretion, and biopsy is contraindicated due to high vascularity.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 110

choices.text: Epitympanum
Mesotympanum
Hypotympanum
Protympanum

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the middle ear lies above the level of the tympanic membrane and typically has a depth of approximately 6 mm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epitympanum

 

The middle ear cavity is divided into three vertical parts relative to the level of the tympanic membrane:

 

  • Also called the attic.
  • Located above the tympanic membrane.
  • Houses the head of malleus and body of incus.
  • Depth is approximately 6 mm.
  • Clinical importance: common site for cholesteatoma formation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mesotympanum: 

 

  • Lies at the level of the tympanic membrane.
  • Depth is about 2 mm.
  • Contains the oval window, round window, and handle of malleus.

 

Option C. Hypotympanum: 

 

  • Located below the tympanic membrane.
  • Depth approximately 4 mm.
  • Close to the jugular bulb.

 

Option D. Protympanum: 

 

  • Not a vertical subdivision.
  • It is the anterior part of the middle ear cavity, leading to the Eustachian tube.
  • Important in ventilation and pressure equalization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epitympanum (attic) lies above the tympanic membrane and is approximately 6 mm deep.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: External carotid artery
Internal jugular vein
Sigmoid sinus
Vertebral artery

questions.text: What important vascular structure lies just beneath the thin bony floor of the middle ear cavity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal jugular vein

 

The floor of the middle ear cavity is also called the jugular wall. It is a thin plate of bone (often dehiscent) that separates the middle ear from the jugular bulb, a dilation of the internal jugular vein.

 

Internal jugular vein lies immediately below the floor of the middle ear cavity.

 

Bulging or dehiscent jugular bulb can present as pulsatile tinnitus, blue mass behind tympanic membrane, or intraoperative bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External carotid artery: This vessel supplies structures in the face and scalp and is not located near the floor of the middle ear.

 

Option C. Sigmoid: Located posteriorly, within the mastoid bone, and forms a part of the venous drainage into the internal jugular vein.

 

Option D. Vertebral artery: Located in the transverse foramina of cervical vertebrae, it has no direct anatomical relation to the middle ear cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thin bony floor of the middle ear cavity separates it from the jugular bulb of the internal jugular vein.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: Round window lies anterosuperior to promontory and receives stapes footplate
Promontory is formed by the basal turn of the cochlea
Facial nerve runs below the round window on the medial wall
Processus cochleariformis marks the posterior limit of the medial wall

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes a structure located on the medial wall of the middle ear cavity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promontory is formed by the basal turn of the cochlea

 

  • The promontory is a bony bulge on the medial wall, created by the first (basal) turn of the cochlea.
  • It lies centrally, between the oval and round windows.

 

For video of endoscopic middle ear anatomy, kindly scan the QR code below: 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Round window lies anterosuperior to promontory and receives stapes footplate : Incorrect

 

  • The round window is located posteroinferior to the promontory, not anterosuperior.
  • The oval window, not the round window, receives the footplate of the stapes.

 

Option C. Facial nerve runs below the round window on the medial wall: Incorrect

 

  • The facial nerve runs horizontally above the oval window, along the medial wall, and then turns posteriorly at the junction with the posterior wall (first genu).

 

Option D. Processus cochleariformis marks the posterior limit of the medial wall: Incorrect

 

  • The processus cochleariformis is located anteriorly on the medial wall.
  • It acts as a pulley for the tendon of tensor tympani and lies below the facial canal, serving as a surgical landmark for facial nerve location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The medial wall of the middle ear includes the promontory formed by the basal turn of the cochlea, the oval and round windows, and the horizontal course of the facial nerve above the oval window.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: Ponticulus is a bony ridge that connects the pyramid to the round window niche
Subiculum is a bony ridge located superior to the ponticulus
Sinus tympani lies between the ponticulus superiorly and the subiculum inferiorly
Cholesteatoma in the sinus tympani is easily visible on otoscopic examination

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the sinus tympani and its related structures is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sinus tympani lies between the ponticulus superiorly and the subiculum inferiorly

 

The sinus tympani is a small recess located in the posterior wall of the middle ear, and is of high clinical significance in otologic surgery, especially in cases of cholesteatoma.

 

  • This is the precise anatomical description of the sinus tympani.
  • It is bounded superiorly by the ponticulus and inferiorly by the subiculum.
  • Cholesteatomas located here may be missed on routine otoscopy due to its deep, hidden location.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ponticulus is a bony ridge that connects the pyramid to the round window niche : Incorrect

 

  • The ponticulus is a bony ridge that connects the promontory to the pyramid, hence remembered by the mnemonic "PPP – Ponticulus connects Promontory to Pyramid".

 

Option B. Subiculum is a bony ridge located superior to the ponticulus: Incorrect

 

  • The subiculum is located inferior to the ponticulus, not superior.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma in the sinus tympani is easily visible on otoscopic examination: Incorrect

 

  • The sinus tympani is a hidden area during otoscopic or even microscopic ear examination.
  • Cholesteatomas here can be missed, which is why it is also called a "surgical blind spot" in ear surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sinus tympani lies between the ponticulus (which connects promontory to pyramid) and the subiculum inferiorly, and is a common site for hidden cholesteatoma formation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5,6

choices.text: The incus is the largest ossicle and is the last to reach adult size after birth
The stapes is the smallest bone in the middle ear but not the smallest in the body
The ossicles grow until puberty and reach adult size by adolescence
The malleus is the largest ossicle and all ossicles attain adult size by birth

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the ossicles of the middle ear is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The malleus is the largest ossicle and all ossicles attain adult size by birth

 

The middle ear contains three ossicles — malleus, incus, and stapes — which play a vital role in transmitting sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear:

  • Among the three ossicles:
    • Malleus is the largest
    • Stapes is the smallest, and also the smallest bone in the entire human body
  • Importantly, all three ossicles reach their full (adult) size by birth, allowing normal conductive hearing from infancy.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The incus is the largest ossicle and is the last to reach adult size after birth: Incorrect

 

  • The incus is not the largest — malleus is.
  • All ossicles, including the incus, attain adult size at birth, not after.

 

Option B. The stapes is the smallest bone in the middle ear but not the smallest in the body: Incorrect

 

  • The stapes is not only the smallest ossicle but also the smallest bone in the entire human body.

 

Option C. The ossicles grow until puberty and reach adult size by adolescence: Incorrect

 

  • The ossicles are unique in that they are fully developed at birth — no further growth occurs during childhood or adolescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The malleus is the largest and the stapes is the smallest ossicle (and smallest bone in the body); all three ossicles attain adult size by birth.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8

choices.text: ASOM
Glomus Jugulare
Acoustic Neuroma
Otosclerosis

questions.text: A 45yr old female presented with gradual onset progressive hearing loss in the right ear associated with pulsatile tinnitus. The tympanic membrane appeared reddish. TFT showed Rinne was negative on the right side, positive on the left and Weber lateralised to the right. Tinnitus temporarily ceased with carotid pressure and auscultation over mastoid revealed an audible bruit. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glomus Jugulare

 

Option B. Glomus Jugulare: This is a vascular tumor of the middle ear. The patient's symptoms of gradual hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus, a reddish tympanic membrane, temporary cessation of tinnitus with carotid pressure (aquino sign), and an audible bruit over the mastoid are classic for a glomus tumor. The negative Rinne test on the affected side and Weber's test lateralizing to the affected side indicate conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with a middle ear pathology like glomus jugulare.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ASOM (Acute Suppurative Otitis Media): This condition typically presents with rapid onset ear pain, fever, and hearing loss. The presentation of pulsatile tinnitus, a reddish tympanic membrane, and a bruit over the mastoid are not characteristic of ASOM.

 

Option C. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): This is a benign tumor of the cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve). It typically presents with gradual hearing loss and tinnitus but does not produce a reddish tympanic membrane or an audible bruit. Also, acoustic neuroma usually causes sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. Otosclerosis: Here, conductive hearing loss with intact tympanic membrane is noted but tinnitus is seen in only few people. And tinnitus, if present, is not pulsatile. Aquino sign is not seen here. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomus jugulare in patients presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss (as indicated by negative Rinne and lateralization of Weber to the affected side), a reddish tympanic membrane, and an audible bruit over the mastoid.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: Biopsy is the investigation of choice to confirm glomus tympanicum
CT scan shows salt and pepper appearance due to tumor vascularity
Most glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines
The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss. Otoscopy reveals a reddish mass behind the intact tympanic membrane that blanches on applying pressure with Siegel’s speculum. Which of the following is true regarding her likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The tumor most likely arises from the promontory and receives blood from the ascending pharyngeal artery

 

  • Correct. This describes glomus tympanicum, fitting the clinical picture given.

 

The patient has classical features of a glomus tympanicum (a type of glomus tumor), the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear, especially in females.

 

Key features include:

 

  • Pulsatile tinnitus, conductive hearing loss
  • Reddish mass behind intact TM → suggests Rising Sun Sign
  • Blanching of mass with pressure via Siegel’s speculum → Brown's Sign
  • Aquino sign: blanching with ipsilateral carotid compression
  • Highly vascular, so biopsy is contraindicated
  • CT scan shows Phelps sign (not salt & pepper)
  • MRI shows salt & pepper appearance
  • Glomus tympanicum arises from the promontory
  • Feeding artery: inferior tympanic branch of ascending pharyngeal artery

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biopsy is the investigation of choice to confirm glomus tympanicum

 

  • Incorrect. Never do biopsy due to risk of uncontrolled bleeding in vascular lesions.

 

Option B. CT scan shows salt and pepper appearance due to tumor vascularity

 

  • Incorrect. Salt and pepper appearance is seen on MRI, not CT.
  • CT shows Phelps sign: obliteration of caroticojugular spine.

 

Option C. Most glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines

 

  • Incorrect. Only ~10% are functional, per the rule of 10.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomus tympanicum is a highly vascular middle ear tumor arising from the promontory, often in females, presenting with pulsatile tinnitus, and is fed by the inferior tympanic branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery; biopsy is contraindicated.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: The tympanic segment of the facial nerve lies above the lateral semicircular canal and below the round window
The labyrinthine segment is the longest and widest part of the facial nerve within the temporal bone
Chorda tympani carries taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue and exits through the stylomastoid foramen
The greater superficial petrosal nerve arises from the geniculate ganglion and carries parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal and nasal glands

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the facial nerve (CN VII) is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The greater superficial petrosal nerve arises from the geniculate ganglion and carries parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal and nasal glands

 

The facial nerve (VII cranial nerve) has motor, sensory, and parasympathetic components, and its course is divided into three parts: intracranial, intratemporal, and extracranial.

 

  • The greater superficial petrosal nerve (GSPN) arises from the geniculate ganglion in the labyrinthine segment.
  • It carries preganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland, nasal mucosa, and palatal glands.
  • This option correctly integrates origin, function, and target.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The tympanic segment of the facial nerve lies above the lateral semicircular canal and below the round window: Incorrect

 

  • The tympanic (horizontal) segment lies above the oval window, below the lateral semicircular canal, not the round window.
  • The round window lies posteroinferior to the oval window.

 

Option B. The labyrinthine segment is the longest and widest part of the facial nerve within the temporal bone: Incorrect

 

  • The labyrinthine segment is actually the shortest (4 mm) and narrowest segment of the facial nerve, making it most susceptible to compression (e.g., Bell’s palsy).
  • It extends from the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus to the geniculate ganglion.

 

Option C. Chorda tympani carries taste from the posterior one-third of the tongue and exits through the stylomastoid foramen: Incorrect

 

  • The chorda tympani:
    • Arises from the vertical (mastoid) segment of the nerve
    • Passes between the incus and malleus
    • Exits through the petrotympanic (Glasserian) fissure, not the stylomastoid foramen
    • Carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and parasympathetic fibers to submandibular and sublingual glands

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greater superficial petrosal nerve arises from the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve and carries parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal, nasal, and palatal glands.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 90

choices.text: 30 dB and 90 dB respectively
60 dB and 120 dB respectively
90 dB and 130 dB respectively
60 dB and 130 dB respectively

questions.text: At approximately what decibel level does a normal conversation occur, and at what level does sound begin to cause discomfort to the ear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 60 dB and 120 dB respectively

 

According to WHO:

 

  • Whisper = 30 dB
  • Normal conversation = 60 dB
  • Shout = 90 dB
  • Discomfort to the ear = 120 dB
  • Pain in the ear = 130 dB

 

So:

 

  • A normal conversation is around 60 dB
  • Discomfort starts at around 120 dB

 

Thus, Option B is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30 dB and 90 dB: 30 dB is whisper level, not normal conversation; 90 dB is shouting, not discomfort

 

Option C. 90 dB and 130 dB: 90 dB is shouting; 130 dB is pain, not initial discomfort

 

Option D. 60 dB and 130 dB: 130 dB causes pain, but discomfort begins earlier at 120 dB

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal conversation occurs at approximately 60 dB, while sound levels above 120 dB begin to cause discomfort to the ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 38

choices.text: Mild conductive hearing loss
Moderate sensorineural hearing loss
Normal hearing
Severe mixed hearing loss

questions.text: A patient’s pure tone audiogram is shown above. Which of the following best describes the hearing status of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Normal hearing

 

In the given pure tone audiogram:

 

  • The Y-axis represents hearing level in decibels (dB) → the lower the value, the better the hearing.
  • The X-axis represents frequency (Hz) → covers speech frequencies from 125 Hz to 8000 Hz.
  • Symbols:
    • O = Right ear air conduction
    • X = Left ear air conduction

 

Interpretation of Graph:

 

  • The hearing thresholds for both ears are around 10–15 dB across all tested frequencies.
  • According to WHO standards:
    • 0–25 dB = Normal hearing
    • 26–40 dB = Slight impairment
    • 41–60 dB = Moderate hearing loss, and so on.

→ So, this graph shows normal hearing sensitivity in both ears.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mild conductive hearing loss – Incorrect

 

  • In conductive hearing loss, air conduction is impaired but bone conduction is normal, leading to an air-bone gap.
  • This audiogram shows no such gap.

 

Option B. Moderate sensorineural hearing loss – Incorrect

 

  • Sensorineural loss shows raised thresholds (above 40 dB), usually sloping with high-frequency loss.
  • Here, thresholds are well within normal range.

 

Option D. Severe mixed hearing loss – Incorrect

 

  • Would show thresholds >60 dB and air-bone gaps.
  • Neither is seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pure tone audiogram with hearing thresholds between 0–25 dB across all frequencies indicates normal hearing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 23

choices.text: Normal hearing
Moderate sensorineural hearing loss
Severe conductive hearing loss
Mixed hearing loss

questions.text: An audiogram shows elevated air conduction thresholds (60–90 dB) and better bone conduction thresholds (40–60 dB) across all frequencies with a consistent air-bone gap. Which of the following is the most accurate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed hearing loss

 

  • Elevated AC and BC thresholds with an air-bone gap = mixed loss.

 

Audiogram Interpretation:

 

  • The blue "X" and "O" lines show air conduction thresholds that are elevated to 60–90 dB, indicating hearing loss.
  • The blue arrow marks below indicate bone conduction thresholds, which are better than air conduction, but still abnormal (around 40–60 dB).
  • This reveals a consistent air-bone gap → hallmark of conductive component.
  • Since both air and bone conduction are elevated, there is also a sensorineural component.

→ Hence, this audiogram represents mixed hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal hearing:

 

  • Normal thresholds: 0–25 dB for both AC and BC.
  • Both AC and BC are elevated here → not normal.

 

Option B. Moderate sensorineural hearing loss:

 

  • SNHL shows both AC and BC elevated but no air-bone gap.
  • Gap is clearly present here → not pure SNHL.

 

Option C. Severe conductive hearing loss:

 

  • Conductive loss shows normal BC with elevated AC and air-bone gap.
  • Here, BC is also elevated, so not purely conductive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An audiogram showing elevated air and bone conduction thresholds with a significant air-bone gap is diagnostic of mixed hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 23

choices.text: Incus, malleus, stapes
Stapes, incus, malleus
Malleus, incus, stapes
Stapes, malleus, incus

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of chronic ear infections and persistent conductive hearing loss. On examination, the otolaryngologist suspects ossicular chain disruption. Which of the following sequences correctly represents the anatomical order of the ossicles in the middle ear from the tympanic membrane to the oval window?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malleus, incus, stapes

 

Option C:

 

This is the correct sequence of the ossicles in the middle ear. The malleus (hammer) is directly attached to the tympanic membrane, the incus (anvil) connects the malleus to the stapes (stirrup), and the stapes footplate fits into the oval window of the cochlea. This arrangement is crucial for the transmission of sound vibrations from the outer ear to the inner ear.

 

The anatomical order of the ossicles in the middle ear, critical for the efficient transmission of sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the inner ear, is malleus, incus, and then stapes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Incus, malleus, stapes: This sequence is incorrect because the malleus, not the incus, is the first ossicle in the chain directly attached to the tympanic membrane.

 

Option B. Stapes, incus, malleus: This sequence is incorrect as it reverses the actual anatomical order of the ossicles. The correct sequence starts with the malleus attached to the tympanic membrane and ends with the stapes at the oval window.

 

Option D. Stapes, malleus, incus: This sequence is also incorrect because it does not follow the natural order of vibration transmission from the tympanic membrane to the oval window.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct anatomical sequence of the ossicles in the middle ear is malleus, incus, stapes, which is essential for the transmission of sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the oval window.

choices.text: Cochlear nucleus
Superior olivary complex
Facial motor nucleus
Lateral lemniscus

questions.text: Which of the following structures acts as the central processing unit (CPU) coordinating the stapedial reflex arc?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superior olivary complex

 

  • Acts as the central processor, coordinating signals from both cochlear nuclei and sending outputs to facial nuclei bilaterally.

 

The stapedial (acoustic) reflex protects the inner ear from loud sounds by contracting the stapedius muscle, which dampens movement of the stapes.

 

Pathway Overview (as shown in the image):

 

Sensory limb:

  • Cochlea → Cochlear nerve → Cochlear nucleus
  • Signal is then relayed to the superior olivary complex, which acts as the central integrator (CPU)

 

Motor limb:

  • From the superior olivary complex, signals travel bilaterally to:
    • Facial motor nucleus → Facial nerve (VII) → Nerve to stapedius → Stapedius muscle contraction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear nucleus: This is the relay station in the sensory limb but not the integrator.

 

Option C. Facial motor nucleus: This is part of the motor limb, not the coordinating center.

 

Option D. Lateral lemniscus: This is a higher auditory pathway structure, not involved in the reflex arc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior olivary complex is the central integration center in the stapedial reflex arc, receiving input from the cochlear nucleus and sending bilateral output to the facial motor nuclei.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 24

choices.text: Otosclerosis
Ménière’s disease
Presbycusis
Noise-induced hearing loss

questions.text: The audiogram shown reveals a bilateral high-frequency sloping sensorineural hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presbycusis

 

  • Age-related bilateral high-frequency SNHL with sloping pattern.

 

Audiogram Interpretation:

 

  • The graph shows:
    • Air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC) thresholds are nearly overlapping → Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
    • Hearing is relatively preserved at low frequencies (125–500 Hz)
    • There is a progressive decline in hearing threshold at higher frequencies (2000–8000 Hz)
    • The pattern is bilateral and symmetric

This is the hallmark pattern of presbycusis, the most common cause of hearing loss in the elderly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otosclerosis:

 

  • Causes conductive hearing loss with a Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz.
  • Would show an air-bone gap, which is absent here.

 

Option B. Ménière’s disease:

 

  • Typically causes low-frequency SNHL and is often unilateral and fluctuating, not symmetric high-frequency loss.

 

Option D. Noise-induced hearing loss:

 

  • Classically shows a notch at 4000 Hz, not the smooth sloping pattern seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A bilateral high-frequency sloping sensorineural hearing loss on audiogram is characteristic of presbycusis.

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 52

choices.text: It is a branch of glossopharyngeal nerve that enters the middle ear through the Eustachian tube
It runs lateral to the tympanic membrane between the incus and the stapes
It carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and taste fibres from posterior one-third of tongue
It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the chorda tympani nerve is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and passes between handle of malleus and long process of incus

 

Taste from anterior 2/3 and path between handle of malleus and long process of incus: Correct

 

Chorda tympani:

  • Is a branch of the facial nerve (CN VII)
  • Enters middle ear through the posterior canaliculus
  • Runs on the medial surface of the tympanic membrane
  • Lies between the handle of malleus and long process of incus, above the tendon of tensor tympani
  • Carries:
    • Taste fibres from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue
    • Preganglionic parasympathetic fibres to submandibular and sublingual glands via submandibular ganglion

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a branch of glossopharyngeal nerve that enters the middle ear through the Eustachian tube: Incorrect. Chorda tympani is from facial nerve, and does not enter via Eustachian tube

 

Option B. It runs lateral to the tympanic membrane between the incus and the stapes: Incorrect. Runs on the medial surface of tympanic membrane, and between malleus and incus, not incus and stapes

 

Option C. It carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland and taste fibres from posterior one-third of tongue: Incorrect. Parotid is supplied by glossopharyngeal; posterior 1/3 taste is via CN IX, not chorda tympani

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorda tympani is a branch of facial nerve that carries taste from anterior two-thirds of tongue and secretomotor fibres to submandibular/sublingual glands, running between the handle of malleus and long process of incus.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8

choices.text: Middle ear cavity – Tegmen antri
Mastoid antrum – Tegmen tympani
Middle ear cavity – Tegmen tympani
Mastoid antrum – Lamina papyracea

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the bony roof of the specified ear structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle ear cavity – Tegmen tympani

 

The tegmen is a thin plate of bone forming the roof of structures in the temporal bone, separating them from the middle cranial fossa (which contains the temporal lobe of the brain). The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear cavity, separating it from the middle cranial fossa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle ear cavity – Tegmen antri: Incorrect. The roof of the middle ear cavity is formed by the tegmen tympani, not tegmen antri.

 

Option B. Mastoid antrum – Tegmen tympani: Incorrect. The roof of the mastoid antrum is the tegmen antri, not tegmen tympani.

 

Option  D. Mastoid antrum – Lamina papyracea: Lamina papyracea forms the medial wall of the orbit, not related to the ear structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear cavity, while the tegmen antri forms the roof of the mastoid antrum.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: Eustachian tube and promontory
Pars flaccida and scutum laterally, and neck of malleus medially
Round window and oval window
Tensor tympani and tympanic membrane

questions.text: Prussak's space is located between which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pars flaccida and scutum laterally, and neck of malleus medially

 

Prussak’s space is a small but clinically significant space in the epitympanum (attic) of the middle ear. It lies:

 

  • Laterally: bounded by the scutum and pars flaccida
  • Medially: bounded by the neck of the malleus

 

This space is the most common site for retraction pocket formation, especially in cases of chronic eustachian tube dysfunction. These pockets may trap keratin debris and evolve into a primary acquired cholesteatoma, which can erode surrounding bony structures such as the scutum, ossicles, and even the facial canal.

 

 

star marked space in the picture

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eustachian tube and promontory: These structures are part of the anterior and medial walls, respectively, but do not define Prussak’s space.

 

Option C. Round window and oval window: These are features on the medial wall of the middle ear, unrelated to Prussak’s space.

 

Option D. Tensor tympani and tympanic membrane: Tensor tympani runs in a canal on the anterior wall and inserts on the handle of malleus, but is not a boundary of Prussak’s space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prussak’s space is bounded by the pars flaccida and scutum laterally and the neck of the malleus medially; it is the most common site for cholesteatoma formation.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 5

choices.text: It is a thick bony ridge separating the facial nerve and sigmoid sinus
It marks the end point of mastoid dissection and signifies completion of cell removal
It is a persistent petrosquamosal suture that may mislead the surgeon during mastoidectomy
It separates the middle ear cavity from the mastoid antrum and blocks disease spread

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Körner’s septum is correct and clinically significant during mastoidectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a persistent petrosquamosal suture that may mislead the surgeon during mastoidectomy

 

Körner’s septum is a thin bony plate, considered the remnant of the petrosquamosal suture, which persists in some individuals and holds clinical importance during mastoidectomy.

 

  • Körner’s septum separates the outer squamous mastoid air cells from the inner petrous mastoid air cells.
  • During surgery, the surgeon may mistakenly interpret this bony septum as the medial limit of dissection and stop drilling, leaving behind disease in the petrous portion.
  • This can lead to residual cholesteatoma or infection.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a thick bony ridge separating the facial nerve and sigmoid sinus: Incorrect

 

  • Körner’s septum is not related to the facial nerve or sigmoid sinus.
  • It is not thick and does not serve as a boundary between neural or vascular structures.

 

Option B. It marks the end point of mastoid dissection and signifies completion of cell removal: Incorrect

 

  • This is the error many surgeons may make.
  • Körner’s septum gives a false impression of completion, but behind it lie petrous air cells that may still harbor disease.

 

Option D. It separates the middle ear cavity from the mastoid antrum and blocks disease spread: Incorrect

 

  • The middle ear cavity and mastoid antrum are connected via the aditus, and Körner’s septum does not separate these two.
  • It is located within the mastoid bone, not between middle ear and mastoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Körner’s septum is a persistent petrosquamosal suture that may mislead the surgeon during mastoidectomy into prematurely stopping drilling, potentially leaving residual disease in the petrous air cells.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 7

choices.text: To amplify high-frequency sounds for vestibular perception
To protect the cochlea from loud sounds via stapedius and tensor tympani reflexes
To compensate for energy loss when sound passes from air in middle ear to fluid in inner ear
To equalize air pressure across the tympanic membrane via the Eustachian tube

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the primary role of the transformer (impedance-matching) mechanism of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To compensate for energy loss when sound passes from air in middle ear to fluid in inner ear

 

When sound waves travel from the air-filled middle ear (a low-density medium) to the fluid-filled inner ear (a high-density medium), a significant portion of energy is lost due to reflection, refraction, and absorption at the interface. Without compensation, we would hear all sounds as muffled or reduced in intensity, similar to how sound feels when you’re underwater hearing someone from outside.

 

To overcome this energy mismatch, the middle ear employs a natural compensatory mechanism known as the:

 

Transformer mechanism or Impedance-matching mechanism

 

This mechanism amplifies the sound energy before it reaches the cochlear fluids so that the energy lost during transmission is offset by energy gained by the ossicular system.

 

  • This is the core function of the transformer mechanism.
  • It ensures that we hear sounds at their original energy despite the change in medium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To amplify high-frequency sounds for vestibular perception: Incorrect

 

  • The vestibular system is for balance, not hearing.
  • Also, the transformer mechanism is not frequency-selective; it works across a range of sound frequencies.

 

Option B. To protect the cochlea from loud sounds via stapedius and tensor tympani reflexes: Incorrect

 

  • This refers to the acoustic reflex, a separate protective mechanism, not related to impedance matching.

 

Option D. To equalize air pressure across the tympanic membrane via the Eustachian tube: Incorrect

 

  • This function pertains to the Eustachian tube, not the transformer mechanism.
  • It ensures tympanic membrane mobility, but not energy matching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transformer (impedance-matching) mechanism of the middle ear compensates for energy loss when sound passes from air to fluid by amplifying it before entry into the inner ear.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 15

choices.text: Stapedius – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by V3
Tensor tympani – 2nd arch – attaches to stapes – supplied by facial nerve
Tensor tympani – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by mandibular nerve
Stapedius – 3rd arch – attaches to footplate of stapes – supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the middle ear muscle with its embryological arch origin, attachment, and nerve supply?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tensor tympani – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by mandibular nerve

 

There are two small muscles in the middle ear involved in modulating sound transmission:

 

Tensor tympani:

 

  • Derived from 1st pharyngeal (branchial) arch
  • Attaches to neck/handle of the malleus
  • Supplied by mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (V3)
  • Function: Tenses the tympanic membrane to dampen loud sounds

 

Stapedius:

 

  • Derived from 2nd pharyngeal arch
  • Attaches to posterior crus of stapes
  • Supplied by facial nerve (CN VII)
  • Function: Stabilizes stapes and prevents excessive vibration

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapedius – 1st arch – attaches to neck of malleus – supplied by V3: Incorrect. Stapedius is from 2nd arch, not 1st; also attaches to stapes, not malleus, and is supplied by facial nerve, not V3.

 

Option B. Tensor tympani – 2nd arch – attaches to stapes – supplied by facial nerve: Incorrect. Tensor tympani is from the 1st arch, not 2nd; attaches to malleus, not stapes, and is supplied by V3, not facial nerve.

 

Option D. Stapedius – 3rd arch – attaches to footplate of stapes – supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve: Incorrect. Stapedius is from 2nd arch, and supplied by facial nerve (VII), not glossopharyngeal (IX).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tensor tympani is a 1st arch muscle that attaches to the malleus and is supplied by mandibular nerve (V3), while stapedius is a 2nd arch muscle that attaches to the stapes and is supplied by the facial nerve (VII).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Mild retraction of the pars flaccida without touching ossicles
Retraction pocket touches the neck of the malleus only
Retraction pocket touches the head and neck of malleus, with partially visible sac contents
Retraction pocket involves head and neck of malleus with erosion of scutum

questions.text: According to the Tos classification of pars flaccida retraction, which of the following best describes Type IV?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Retraction pocket involves head and neck of malleus with erosion of scutum

 

The Tos classification is used to grade retractions of the pars flaccida, which can lead to cholesteatoma formation. It is based on the extent of retraction, ossicular involvement, and bony erosion.

 

Other Options:

 

Type 0:

  • Normal anatomy – no retraction

 

Type I:

  • Mild retraction of pars flaccida
  • Does not contact ossicles
  • Option A fits Type I – Not Type IV

 

Type II:

  • Retraction pocket touches the neck of the malleus
  • Option B fits Type II – Not Type IV

 

Type III:

  • Retraction pocket touches head and neck of malleus
  • Contents of sac partially visible
  • Option C fits Type III – Not Type IV

 

Type IV:

  • Type III + erosion of the scutum

 

 

D) Retraction pocket involves head and neck of malleus with erosion of scutum – Correct for Type IV

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Tos classification, Type IV pars flaccida retraction involves the head and neck of the malleus with erosion of the scutum.

choices.text: 15–20 dB
20–30 dB
30–45 dB
45–60 dB

questions.text: A patient is Rinne negative with 256 Hz and 512 Hz tuning forks, but Rinne positive with 1024 Hz tuning fork. What is the most likely approximate degree of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30–45 dB

 

The Rinne test is used to differentiate between air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC) hearing. The frequency of the tuning fork used also plays a role in estimating the degree of hearing loss, especially conductive hearing loss.

 

According to the provided data:

 

  • Rinne negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz → ~20–30 dB loss
  • Rinne negative for 256 & 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz → ~30–45 dB loss 
  • Rinne negative for 256, 512 & 1024 Hz → ~45–60 dB loss

 

So in this case:

 

  • Rinne negative for 256 & 512 Hz
  • Rinne positive for 1024 Hz
    → Matches with 30–45 dB hearing loss

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 15–20 dB: Too mild for a negative Rinne with 512 Hz

 

Option B. 20–30 dB: Would be seen if only 256 Hz showed negative Rinne

 

Option D. 45–60 dB: Seen only if all three (256, 512, 1024 Hz) are Rinne negative

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rinne negative with 256 & 512 Hz but positive with 1024 Hz indicates a conductive hearing loss of approximately 30–45 dB.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: 26–40 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in normal voice at 1 m
41–60 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in raised voice at 1 m
61–80 dB hearing loss, able to hear only when shouted into the better ear
≥81 dB hearing loss, unable to hear even a shouted voice

questions.text: According to the WHO classification of hearing impairment, which of the following best corresponds to moderate hearing impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 41–60 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in raised voice at 1 m

 

According to the WHO classification of hearing impairment:

 

Grade 0: No Impairment

  • ≤25 dB
  • Can hear whispers
  • No hearing problems

 

Grade 1: Slight Impairment

  • 26–40 dB
  • Can hear normal voice at 1 m
  • Counseling may help

 

Grade 2: Moderate Impairment

  • 41–60 dB
  • Needs raised voice at 1 m
  • Hearing aids usually recommended
    → Correct match for Option B

 

Grade 3: Severe Impairment

  • 61–80 dB
  • Can hear only when shouted into better ear

 

Grade 4: Profound Impairment / Deafness

  • ≥81 dB
  • Cannot understand even shouted voice
  • Needs lip-reading or signing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 26–40 dB hearing loss, able to repeat words spoken in normal voice at 1 m: Normal voice at 1 m – This is slight impairment

 

Option C. 61–80 dB hearing loss, able to hear only when shouted into the better ear: Shouted into better ear – This is severe impairment

 

Option D. ≥81 dB hearing loss, unable to hear even a shouted voice: Unable to hear even shouted voice – This is profound impairment

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO classifies moderate hearing impairment as 41–60 dB hearing loss, where the person can hear and repeat words spoken in a raised voice at 1 meter.

 

Ref: Report of the informal working group on prevention of deafness and hearing impairment programme planning, Geneva, 18-21 June 1991. Geneva: World Health Organization; 1991.

choices.text: Normal hearing
Mild sensorineural hearing loss
Mild conductive hearing loss
Mild mixed hearing loss
