questions.text: The audiogram shown demonstrates which of the following types of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mild conductive hearing loss

 

Let’s interpret the audiogram systematically:

 

Key symbols:

 

  • “X” = Air conduction thresholds for left ear
  • “[” = Bone conduction thresholds for left ear

 

What the graph shows:

 

  • The air conduction thresholds are around 35–40 dB across all frequencies.
  • The bone conduction thresholds are around 10–15 dB across the same frequencies.
  • There is a consistent air-bone gap of approximately 20–25 dB.
  • Bone conduction is within normal limits, while air conduction is elevated → Conductive hearing loss.

Mild conductive hearing loss – Correct

  • Defined by normal bone conduction and impaired air conduction with an air-bone gap.
  • Hearing thresholds for AC ~35–40 dB = mild loss.
  • Classic pattern shown in this audiogram.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal hearing:

 

  • Would require both AC and BC thresholds ≤ 25 dB.
  • Here, AC thresholds are above normal.

 

Option B. Mild sensorineural hearing loss:

 

  • Would show both AC and BC elevated, with no air-bone gap.
  • Not seen here.

 

Option D. Mild mixed hearing loss:

 

  • Would show both AC and BC elevated, with an air-bone gap.
  • BC here is normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An audiogram with normal bone conduction, elevated air conduction, and a consistent air-bone gap indicates mild conductive hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 23

choices.text: Presbycusis
Ototoxic hearing loss
Noise-induced hearing loss
Sudden sensorineural hearing loss

questions.text: The given audiogram shows a bilateral dip in hearing threshold around 4000 Hz with preserved hearing in lower frequencies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Noise-induced hearing loss

 

  • Hallmark = 4 kHz dip with relatively normal hearing in lower and higher frequencies.
  • Affects both air and bone conduction (i.e., sensorineural pattern).

 

Let’s interpret the audiogram in detail:

 

  • The Y-axis represents hearing level in decibels (dB).
  • The X-axis represents frequency in Hz.
  • Symbols:
    • Red O = Right ear air conduction
    • Blue X = Left ear air conduction
    • < and > = bone conduction (masked/unmasked)
  • There is a sharp dip at 4000 Hz, followed by recovery at 6000–8000 Hz.
  • Low frequencies are preserved, and the pattern is bilateral and symmetric.

This configuration is classic for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) — also called the "noise notch" at 4 kHz, due to mechanical and metabolic damage from chronic or acute exposure to loud sound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presbycusis:

 

  • Age-related SNHL typically affects high frequencies first, starting from 2–4 kHz and progressing to 8 kHz and beyond.
  • It is more sloping and gradual, not a sharp 4 kHz notch.

 

Option B. Ototoxic hearing loss:

 

  • Seen with drugs like aminoglycosides and cisplatin.
  • Usually starts at ultra-high frequencies (>8 kHz) and then progresses downward.
  • Not limited to a 4 kHz dip.

 

Option D. Sudden sensorineural hearing loss:

 

  • Presents with abrupt hearing loss in one ear, often across all frequencies, not localized to 4 kHz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A 4 kHz dip on audiogram with preserved low and high frequencies is characteristic of noise-induced hearing loss.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 23

choices.text: 8 hours
4 hours
1 hour
15 minutes

questions.text: A factory worker is routinely exposed to noise levels of 94 dB during machinery operation. According to occupational safety guidelines, what is the maximum permissible daily exposure duration without hearing protection at this noise level?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 hour

 

1 hour – Correct. Matches the recommended limit for 94 dB.

 

The NIOSH (National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health) guidelines follow the 3 dB exchange rule, which states that:

 

For every 3 dB increase in noise level above 85 dB, the permissible exposure duration is halved.

 

From the table:

 

  • 85 dB → 8 hours
  • 88 dB → 4 hours
  • 91 dB → 2 hours
  • 94 dB → 1 hour

 

This means that exposure to 94 dB beyond 1 hour requires the use of hearing protection such as earplugs or earmuffs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 8 hours: Safe only for 85 dB, not for 94 dB.

 

Option B. 4 hours: Safe for 88 dB, not for 94 dB.

 

Option D. 15 minutes: This is the safe limit for 100 dB, not 94 dB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At 94 dB, the maximum safe daily exposure without hearing protection is 1 hour, following the 3 dB exchange rule.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 38

choices.text: Noise-induced hearing loss
Otitis externa
Facial nerve palsy proximal to the stapedius branch
Presbycusis

questions.text: Which of the following clinical scenarios is most likely to show an absent stapedial reflex on tympanometry despite a normal cochlea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Facial nerve palsy proximal to the stapedius branch

 

The stapedial reflex depends on both sensory (VIII nerve) and motor (VII nerve) components. If any part of the reflex arc is disrupted, the reflex is absent.

  • The nerve to stapedius arises from the facial nerve before it exits the stylomastoid foramen.
  • In cases of Bell’s palsy or facial nerve injury proximal to the stapedius branch, the reflex is absent, even if hearing is normal.
  • This is useful to localize the lesion in facial palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Noise-induced hearing loss:

 

  • Sensorineural pathology.
  • Reflex may be present if cochlear function is only mildly impaired and the rest of the arc is intact.

 

Option B. Otitis externa:

 

  • External ear pathology does not affect middle ear mechanics or reflex arc.

 

Option D. Presbycusis:

 

  • Age-related SNHL; reflex may be preserved in early stages.
  • Loss is usually bilateral and symmetric, and reflex may still be elicited in mild cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An absent stapedial reflex with a normal cochlea suggests a lesion in the facial nerve proximal to the nerve to stapedius.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 24

choices.text: Present in both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss
Absent in conductive hearing loss due to impaired cochlear function
Absent in sensorineural hearing loss due to middle ear impedance mismatch
Absent in conductive hearing loss due to insufficient sound transmission to cochlea

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the effect of hearing loss on the presence of the stapedial reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Absent in conductive hearing loss due to insufficient sound transmission to cochlea

 

The stapedial reflex requires sufficient acoustic stimulation of the cochlea to activate the reflex arc:

 

Conductive Hearing Loss (CHL):

 

  • Air-borne sound is dampened by middle ear pathology (e.g., fluid, ossicular fixation).
  • Cochlea is intact, but insufficient stimulus reaches it.
  • Result: Absent stapedial reflex

Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL):

  • Reflex may be:
    • Present in mild to moderate SNHL
    • Absent or elevated threshold in severe to profound SNHL (due to cochlear or auditory nerve damage)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Present in both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss: Reflex is often absent in CHL and may be variable in SNHL.

 

Option B. Absent in conductive hearing loss due to impaired cochlear function: Cochlea is normal in CHL; the problem is mechanical transmission.

 

Option C. Absent in sensorineural hearing loss due to middle ear impedance mismatch: SNHL is inner ear pathology; middle ear is usually normal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stapedial reflex is absent in conductive hearing loss due to poor sound conduction to the cochlea, despite a normal neural reflex arc.

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 24

choices.text: Tensor tympani arises from the second pharyngeal arch and is supplied by facial nerve
Stapedius attaches to the malleus and tenses the tympanic membrane
Stapedius is supplied by a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3)
Tensor tympani is supplied by the mandibular nerve and dampens vibrations via the malleus

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intratympanic muscles is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tensor tympani is supplied by the mandibular nerve and dampens vibrations via the malleus

 

There are two intratympanic muscles:

 

  1. Tensor tympani
    • Origin: First pharyngeal arch
    • Attachment: Neck of malleus
    • Innervation: Mandibular nerve (V3)
    • Function: Tenses tympanic membrane; reduces sound vibrations
  2. Stapedius
    • Origin: Second pharyngeal arch
    • Attachment: Neck of stapes
    • Innervation: Facial nerve (CN VII)
    • Function: Dampens loud sounds, protects inner ear from noise trauma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tensor tympani arises from the second pharyngeal arch and is supplied by facial nerve: Incorrect. Tensor tympani is from the first arch, not second.

 

Option B. Stapedius attaches to the malleus and tenses the tympanic membrane: Incorrect. Stapedius attaches to the stapes, not the malleus.

 

Option C. Stapedius is supplied by a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3): Incorrect. Stapedius is supplied by facial nerve (CN VII).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tensor tympani is a first arch muscle supplied by mandibular nerve (V3) and attaches to the malleus to reduce sound vibrations.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 7

choices.text: Formed by tympanic branch of vagus and supplies external auditory canal
Lies on the promontory and supplies lateral surface of tympanic membrane
Formed by tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal and sympathetic fibres, and contributes secretomotor fibres to parotid gland
Supplies motor innervation to the tensor tympani and stapedius muscles

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the tympanic plexus and its functional role?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Formed by tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal and sympathetic fibres, and contributes secretomotor fibres to parotid gland

 

The tympanic plexus:

  • Location: Lies on the promontory (basal coil of cochlea) in the middle ear
  • Formation:
    1. Tympanic branch of CN IX (glossopharyngeal) – sensory + secretomotor
    2. Sympathetic fibres from the internal carotid plexus
  • Supplies:
    • Medial surface of tympanic membrane
    • Tympanic cavity
    • Mastoid air cells
    • Bony part of the eustachian tube

It also plays a key role in the parasympathetic pathway to the parotid gland:

  • Pathway:
    Inferior salivatory nucleus → CN IX → Tympanic branch → Tympanic plexus → Lesser petrosal nerve → Otic ganglion → Auriculotemporal nerve → Parotid gland

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formed by tympanic branch of vagus and supplies external auditory canal: Incorrect. It's the glossopharyngeal nerve, not vagus. Also, supplies middle ear, not external canal.

 

Option B. Lies on the promontory and supplies lateral surface of tympanic membrane: Incorrect. Tympanic plexus supplies the medial surface.

 

Option D. Supplies motor innervation to the tensor tympani and stapedius muscles: Incorrect. Motor to tensor tympani is via V3, and to stapedius via facial nerve, not the tympanic plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tympanic plexus, formed by the tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve and sympathetic fibres, supplies the middle ear and carries secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland via the lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8

choices.text: Cartilaginous Eustachian tube – stratified squamous epithelium
Bony part of Eustachian tube – pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium
Mastoid air cells – flat nonciliated epithelium
Posterior tympanic cavity – ciliated columnar epithelium

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matches the epithelial lining with its respective region in the middle ear or Eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mastoid air cells – flat nonciliated epithelium

 

Mastoid air cells – flat nonciliated epithelium: Correct as per standard histology and your content

 

Eustachian Tube:

  • Cartilaginous part: Pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium with mucous glands
  • Bony part: Columnar epithelium (not ciliated)

Tympanic Cavity:

  • Anterior and inferior parts: Ciliated columnar epithelium
  • Posterior part: Cuboidal epithelium

Epitympanum & Mastoid Air Cells:

  • Flat, nonciliated epithelium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cartilaginous Eustachian tube – stratified squamous epithelium: Incorrect. It is pseudostratified columnar ciliated, not stratified squamous

 

Option B. Bony part of Eustachian tube – pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium: Incorrect. Bony part has simple columnar, not pseudostratified ciliated

 

Option D. Posterior tympanic cavity – ciliated columnar epithelium: Incorrect. Posterior part has cuboidal epithelium, not ciliated columnar

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mastoid air cells and epitympanum are lined by flat, nonciliated epithelium, while the Eustachian tube and tympanic cavity have ciliated or columnar epithelium depending on region.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 8

choices.text: Bone conduction bypasses the cochlea and stimulates the tympanic membrane directly
Air conduction is absent due to ossicular discontinuity
Sound is transmitted via bone to the opposite normal cochlea, leading to a false negative Rinne
The patient has mixed hearing loss with preserved air conduction on the opposite ear

questions.text: A patient with suspected unilateral hearing loss undergoes Rinne’s test, which is negative on the affected side. However, bone conduction is falsely perceived despite a suspected sensorineural lesion. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sound is transmitted via bone to the opposite normal cochlea, leading to a false negative Rinne

 

A false negative Rinne test occurs in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (dead ear):

  • When a tuning fork is placed on the mastoid of the affected ear, bone-conducted sound travels across the skull and is actually heard by the contralateral (normal) ear, not the test ear.
  • Since the patient perceives the sound after bone conduction, but not via air conduction, it falsely appears as a conductive hearing loss (i.e., Rinne negative).
  • In reality, this is profound sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive.

To confirm the diagnosis:

  • Mask the better ear using Barany’s noise box or similar masking technique.
  • Perform Weber test, which will lateralize to the better ear in sensorineural loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone conduction bypasses the cochlea and stimulates the tympanic membrane directly: Incorrect. Bone conduction stimulates cochlea, not tympanic membrane.

 

Option B. Air conduction is absent due to ossicular discontinuity: Seen in conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural loss with transcranial perception.

 

Option D. The patient has mixed hearing loss with preserved air conduction on the opposite ear: Misleading; air conduction is not preserved in the affected ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In unilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss, Rinne test may appear falsely negative due to transcranial transmission of bone-conducted sound to the better ear.

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner perceive the sound for a shorter duration, whereas in sensorineural hearing loss, the durations are equal.
In conductive hearing loss, the patient hears the tuning fork for a shorter duration than the examiner, while in sensorineural hearing loss the durations are equal.
In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for the same duration; in sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears it for a shorter duration than the examiner.
In both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner.

questions.text: In the Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) test, both the patient and a normal-hearing examiner have their external auditory meatus occluded. Which of the following correctly describes the expected findings in a patient with sensorineural hearing loss compared to conductive hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner hear the tuning fork for the same duration; in sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears it for a shorter duration than the examiner.

 

  • Accurately reflects that, in conductive loss, the lesion is mechanical and cochlear function is preserved (equal duration), whereas in SNHL, the patient's reduced cochlear function results in a shorter duration.

The Absolute Bone Conduction (ABC) test is used to assess cochlear function by comparing the duration of the bone-conducted sound (via a tuning fork) as heard by the patient against that of a normal-hearing examiner. Essential points include:

  • External auditory meatus occlusion: Both the patient and examiner occlude their ears (e.g., by pressing the tragus inward) to prevent ambient air-conducted sound interference.
  • Conductive Hearing Loss:
    • The lesion is in the middle ear.
    • The cochlea is intact.
    • Thus, both patient and examiner will perceive the tuning fork sound for approximately the same duration.
  • Sensorineural Hearing Loss (SNHL):
    • The loss is due to impaired cochlear or neural function.
    • The patient will detect the bone-conducted sound for a shorter duration compared to the examiner (who has normal cochlear function).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In conductive hearing loss, both patient and examiner perceive the sound for a shorter duration, whereas in sensorineural hearing loss, the durations are equal: Incorrect. It reverses the expected findings. In SNHL, the patient hears for a shorter duration, not equal to the examiner.

 

Option B. In conductive hearing loss, the patient hears the tuning fork for a shorter duration than the examiner, while in sensorineural hearing loss the durations are equal: Incorrect. States that in conductive loss the patient hears for a shorter duration, which is not true because the cochlea is normal.

 

Option D. In both conductive and sensorineural hearing loss, the patient hears the tuning fork for a longer duration than the examiner. Incorrect. Misstates that in both types the patient hears longer than the examiner; this is not the case in either condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ABC test shows equal duration of bone conduction in conductive hearing loss but a reduced duration in sensorineural hearing loss due to impaired cochlear function.

 

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: Sound is louder when the ear canal is occluded (Bing positive)
Sound is softer when the ear canal is occluded
No change in sound perception with occlusion (Bing negative)
Sound is louder only when both ears are occluded

questions.text: In the Bing test, a tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the ear canal is alternately closed and opened. Which of the following findings indicates conductive hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No change in sound perception with occlusion (Bing negative)

 

  • This is Bing negative, seen in conductive hearing loss

Bing Test:

  • Evaluates the occlusion effect on bone conduction
  • A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid process
  • The tragus is pressed to close the ear canal, then released to open it
  • Normal or SNHL: Patient hears louder sound with occlusion (called Bing positive)
  • Conductive Hearing Loss (CHL): There is no change in perceived loudness (called Bing negative), because sound already cannot reach the cochlea via the air route

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sound is louder when the ear canal is occluded (Bing positive): Seen in normal or SNHL, not CHL → Bing positive

 

Option B. Sound is softer when the ear canal is occluded: Not a typical finding in any of the standard hearing patterns

 

Option D. Sound is louder only when both ears are occluded: Not a standard step in Bing test; only the test ear is occluded

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bing test is negative (no change with occlusion) in conductive hearing loss and positive (sound gets louder with occlusion) in normal or sensorineural hearing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: Normal hearing
Sensorineural hearing loss
Otitis externa
Otosclerosis with stapes fixation

questions.text: Gelle’s test is performed using a vibrating tuning fork on the mastoid while air pressure is increased in the ear canal using a Siegel’s speculum. In which of the following conditions will the patient perceive no change in the loudness of sound during the test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Otosclerosis with stapes fixation

 

  • Gelle’s test is negative due to fixed ossicular chain

Gelle’s test is used to evaluate the mobility of the ossicular chain, especially the stapes:

  • A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid.
  • A Siegel’s speculum is used to increase air pressure in the external auditory canal.
  • In normal ears or those with sensorineural hearing loss, increased air pressure pushes the TM and ossicles inward, affecting cochlear mechanics and resulting in decreased perception of bone-conducted sound → Gelle’s test positive
  • In conductive hearing loss due to ossicular fixation (e.g., otosclerosis) or ossicular discontinuity, there is no change in perceived sound → Gelle’s test negative

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal hearing: Gelle’s test would be positive (sound gets softer with pressure change)

 

Option B. Sensorineural hearing loss: Gelle’s test also positive as ossicles are mobile

 

Option C. Otitis externa: External canal disease doesn't affect ossicle mobility; not relevant for Gelle’s test

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gelle’s test is negative (no change in bone-conducted sound) in ossicular fixation or discontinuity, such as in otosclerosis, and positive in normal and sensorineural hearing.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 22

choices.text: Otosclerosis is an autosomal recessive condition with complete penetrance
It is more common in females globally, but in India, males are more commonly affected
Otosclerosis commonly begins after 40 years of age
The most common site of origin is the round window membrane

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the etiology of otosclerosis is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is more common in females globally, but in India, males are more commonly affected

 

It’s female-predominant globally but male-predominant in India

 

The etiology of otosclerosis involves multiple factors:

 

Anatomical basis:

 

  • The fissula ante fenestram (anterior to oval window) is the most common site of spongy bone formation.
  • This occurs in enchondral bone, typically dormant, but cartilage rests get activated.

 

Genetics:

 

  • It is an autosomal dominant condition with incomplete penetrance and variable expressivity.

 

Demographics:

 

  • More common in females, globally → 2:1 female-to-male ratio
  • But in India, males predominate

 

Age:

 

  • Onset is typically between 20–30 years
  • Rare before 10 or after 40

 

Other associations:

 

  • Can worsen in pregnancy, menopause, or post trauma/surgery.
  • Associated with osteogenesis imperfecta → seen in Van der Hoeve syndrome (otosclerosis + blue sclera + fractures)

 

Viral Theory:

 

  • Measles virus RNA has been detected in otosclerotic foci.
  • Suggested to have viral etiology, similar to Paget’s disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otosclerosis is an autosomal recessive condition with complete penetrance: Incorrect. It is autosomal dominant, not recessive, and penetrance is incomplete

 

Option C. Otosclerosis commonly begins after 40 years of age: Incorrect. Onset is between 20–30 years, rare after 40

 

Option D. The most common site of origin is the round window membrane: Incorrect: The oval window (specifically fissula ante fenestram) is the most common site, not round window

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otosclerosis is an autosomal dominant disease affecting the enchondral bone at the fissula ante fenestram, more common in females globally, but in males in India, with onset typically between 20–30 years.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Stapedial otosclerosis is asymptomatic and causes no hearing loss
Cochlear otosclerosis is the most common and causes conductive hearing loss
Histologic otosclerosis shows bony changes but no clinical hearing impairment
Obliterative type of cochlear otosclerosis causes complete fixation of the stapes footplate

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly matches the type of otosclerosis with its characteristic feature?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histologic otosclerosis shows bony changes but no clinical hearing impairment

 

Histologic otosclerosis causes no clinical symptoms; changes are only seen microscopically

 

There are three recognized types of otosclerosis based on site and clinical impact:

 

 1. Stapedial Otosclerosis (Most common):

 

  • Lesion starts in fissula ante fenestram (anterior to oval window)
  • Leads to stapes footplate fixation → conductive hearing loss
  • Variants include:
    • Anterior focus, posterior focus
    • Circumferential (around stapes margin)
    • Biscuit type (footplate fixed, annular ligament free)
    • Obliterative type (complete closure of oval window niche)

 

 2. Cochlear Otosclerosis:

 

  • Involves round window region or otic capsule
  • Leads to sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), likely due to toxic metabolite release into perilymph

 

 3. Histologic Otosclerosis:

 

  • Microscopic foci seen in otic capsule, but no hearing loss
  • Detected only on histopathology
  • Clinically asymptomatic

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapedial otosclerosis is asymptomatic and causes no hearing loss: Incorrect. Stapedial otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss, not asymptomatic

 

Option B. Cochlear otosclerosis is the most common and causes conductive hearing loss: Incorrect. Cochlear otosclerosis causes sensorineural hearing loss, and it’s not the most common (stapedial is)

 

Option D. Obliterative type of cochlear otosclerosis causes complete fixation of the stapes footplate: Incorrect. Obliterative type is a variant of stapedial otosclerosis, not cochlear

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histologic otosclerosis is asymptomatic, while stapedial and cochlear types cause conductive and sensorineural hearing loss respectively, depending on the site of involvement.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 86

choices.text: Vestibular schwannoma
Glomus tympanicum
Glomus jugulare
Cholesteatoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with pulsatile tinnitus and progressive hearing loss. On examination, a reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane. She also complains of hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Imaging reveals a lesion involving the jugular foramen and hypotympanum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glomus jugulare

 

This tumor arises from the dome of the jugular bulb, invades the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, leading to compression or invasion of the jugular vein and neurological signs involving cranial nerves IX–XII, such as hoarseness (vagus nerve) and dysphagia (glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves). This best matches the clinical scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vestibular schwannoma: Incorrect. It arises from the vestibular nerve (CN VIII) in the internal auditory canal or cerebellopontine angle, not from the middle ear or jugular bulb. It does not invade the hypotympanum or jugular foramen and does not typically cause lower cranial nerve palsies (IX–XII) early.

 

Option B. Glomus tympanicum: Incorrect. It arises from the promontory of the middle ear. It can cause aural symptoms like hearing loss or tinnitus, and sometimes facial paralysis, but does not involve the jugular foramen or cause lower cranial nerve symptoms.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: Incorrect. While it may cause hearing loss and chronic ear discharge, it does not originate from vascular structures, does not appear as a pulsatile mass, and typically does not cause cranial nerve IX–XII involvement.

 

Educational Objective:


Glomus jugulare tumors arise from the dome of the jugular bulb, invade the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, and may cause lower cranial nerve (IX–XII) involvement and vascular compression.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: It commonly metastasizes to liver and kidneys in over 10% of cases
It can spread intracranially to posterior and middle cranial fossae
It never involves the eustachian tube or nasopharynx
It originates from the cochlea and spreads to the tympanic membrane

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with pulsatile tinnitus, hearing loss, and hoarseness. Otoscopy reveals a reddish mass behind a perforated tympanic membrane. Imaging shows invasion of the mastoid, jugular foramen, and extension toward the nasopharynx. Which of the following statements about the spread of the suspected tumor is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It can spread intracranially to posterior and middle cranial fossae


Glomus tumors can spread intracranially, especially into the posterior and middle cranial fossae, as part of their locally aggressive behavior. This matches the described findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It commonly metastasizes to liver and kidneys in over 10% of cases: Incorrect. Metastatic spread is rare, seen in only ~4% of cases, and typically involves lungs and bones, not liver and kidneys.

 

Option C. It never involves the eustachian tube or nasopharynx: Incorrect. These tumors can spread via the Eustachian tube, and present in the nasopharynx, which is important to recognize, especially when evaluating a nasopharyngeal mass with vascular characteristics.

 

Option D. It originates from the cochlea and spreads to the tympanic membrane: Incorrect. Glomus tumors do not originate from the cochlea; they arise from paraganglionic tissue, such as that in the jugular bulb (glomus jugulare) or middle ear promontory (glomus tympanicum). They may perforate the tympanic membrane secondarily.

 

Educational Objective:


Glomus tumors may spread locally to the middle ear, mastoid, skull base, nasopharynx, and intracranial fossae, and rarely metastasize to lungs or bones (4%).

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 109

choices.text: It typically presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss
Brown’s sign is usually negative
Cranial nerves IX to XII may be involved in late stages
The tumor may produce catecholamines, causing systemic symptoms

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with right-sided pulsatile tinnitus, slowly progressive hearing loss, and occasional dizziness. Otoscopy reveals a bluish, bulging tympanic membrane with a red mass visible behind it. The mass blanches and pulsates with pressure applied via Siegel’s speculum. She also complains of mild hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Which of the following is not true regarding the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brown’s sign is usually negative


Brown’s sign is positive in glomus tumors. It refers to vigorous pulsation and blanching of the tumor when pressure is applied via Siegel’s speculum, and reversal upon release.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It typically presents with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss: Correct. Glomus tumors most commonly present with pulsatile tinnitus and slowly progressive conductive hearing loss due to intratympanic location. These are the earliest symptoms in 90% of cases.

 

Option C. Cranial nerves IX to XII may be involved in late stages: Correct. Cranial nerves IX to XII may be involved in later stages, leading to dysphagia, hoarseness, palatal paralysis, and tongue atrophy, as the tumor invades the jugular foramen and skull base.

 

Option D. The tumor may produce catecholamines, causing systemic symptoms: Correct. Some glomus tumors are functionally active, secreting catecholamines, which cause systemic symptoms like palpitations, hypertension, sweating, and anxiety. These cases need further endocrine work-up.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glomus tumors commonly cause pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss, show positive Brown’s sign, may involve lower cranial nerves in late stages, and can occasionally secrete catecholamines.

 

Ref: P.L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck Surgery 6th Edition, pg 109
